domains.name: Technical Architecture
domains.description: Artifacts and specifications that define how the Product is built and operated, including system structure, data and AI architecture, APIs and integrations, security, infrastructure, operational tooling, and validation before implementation.

terms.name: System
terms.definition: The complete set of software and infrastructure components that collectively deliver the Productâ€™s functionality.
terms.description: Defines the full boundary of what is being built and operated, including runtime services, data stores, integrations, and infrastructure resources.

terms.name: System Architecture
terms.definition: A structured description of how all elements of the System are organized and interact, including client, server, database, integration, and infrastructure layers.
terms.description: Defines the high-level blueprint of components and interactions to reduce complexity and enable consistent implementation decisions.

terms.name: Architecture Layers
terms.definition: A structured definition of distinct levels within the System Architecture, each responsible for a specific type of functionality.
terms.description: Defines boundaries and responsibilities per layer to control coupling and clarify where logic, data access, and integrations belong.

terms.name: System Components
terms.definition: Distinct functional modules or subsystems that collectively form the System, such as services, gateways, or processing units.
terms.description: Defines what the system is composed of and how responsibilities are split for scalability, maintainability, and ownership clarity.

terms.name: Technology Stack
terms.definition: The set of technologies selected to build and operate the System, including frameworks, libraries, platforms, and tools.
terms.description: Defines the concrete implementation toolkit to standardize development, deployment, and operation across the product lifecycle.

terms.name: Technology Rationale
terms.definition: A documented justification for selecting specific technologies in terms of scalability, maintainability, performance, team capability, and viability.
terms.description: Explains why each major technology choice is appropriate, enabling review, long-term maintainability, and replacement decisions.

terms.name: Data Model
terms.definition: A conceptual description of all entities, their attributes, and relationships used within the System.
terms.description: Defines what data exists and how it relates conceptually, enabling consistent interpretation across APIs, storage, and business logic.

terms.name: Logical Data Model
terms.definition: A detailed representation of data entities and relationships independent of physical database implementation.
terms.description: Defines entity structure and cardinality with business semantics to bridge conceptual modeling and physical schema design.

terms.name: Entity Definitions
terms.definition: Clear descriptions of all entities in the Data Model, including purpose, meaning, and role in the system.
terms.description: Clarifies how each entity should be interpreted and used to prevent inconsistent implementation and ambiguous API semantics.

terms.name: Database Schema
terms.definition: An implementation-level structure of the database including tables, columns, keys, data types, constraints, and indexes.
terms.description: Defines how data is physically stored and validated to support performance, integrity, and predictable query behavior.

terms.name: Keys and Constraints
terms.definition: Rules governing data integrity within the Database Schema, including primary keys, foreign keys, uniqueness, and validations.
terms.description: Enforces correctness and relational structure so invalid states are prevented at the storage layer.

terms.name: Indexing Strategy
terms.definition: A structured approach defining database indexes required to optimize query performance and scalability.
terms.description: Defines which access patterns must be fast and how indexes support them while controlling write overhead.

terms.name: Data Architecture Overview
terms.definition: A structured description of data domains, system-of-records, ownership, and major storage/processing locations across the System.
terms.description: Defines how data is partitioned by domain and where authoritative sources live to prevent duplication and conflicting truth.

terms.name: Data Flow and Lineage
terms.definition: A mapping of how data moves through sources, transformations, storage, and consumers, including origin and downstream dependencies.
terms.description: Shows where data comes from, how it changes, and where it is used to support debugging, impact analysis, and governance.

terms.name: Data Quality Rules
terms.definition: Defined validation and monitoring rules ensuring data correctness, completeness, consistency, and anomaly detection.
terms.description: Specifies which data properties must hold true and how violations are detected and handled.

terms.name: Data Governance and Access Model
terms.definition: A structured definition of data classification, access policies, audit requirements, and ownership responsibilities.
terms.description: Defines who can access which data and under what rules, including PII handling and auditability expectations.

terms.name: Data Lifecycle Rules
terms.definition: Constraints defining retention, archival, deletion, and disposal behavior for each data domain, including PII handling requirements.
terms.description: Defines how long data is stored, how it is removed, and how lifecycle actions are verified and audited.

terms.name: Backup and Recovery Strategy
terms.definition: A plan defining backup frequency, retention, restore procedures, and recovery objectives such as RPO and RTO.
terms.description: Defines how the system recovers from data loss or corruption, including restore testing and operational responsibilities.

terms.name: API Architecture
terms.definition: The structured design of application programming interfaces, including endpoint inventory, request/response structures, authentication rules, and error standards.
terms.description: Defines how system capabilities are exposed and consumed, enabling consistent integration between frontend, backend, and external systems.

terms.name: API Structures
terms.definition: Defined input and output formats for API endpoints, including fields, data types, validation rules, and object shapes.
terms.description: Defines exact contracts to eliminate ambiguity, enable type-safe clients, and support automated validation.

terms.name: API Error Handling
terms.definition: A standardized system for representing and communicating API errors, including error codes, response formats, and messaging rules.
terms.description: Defines predictable failure responses to simplify debugging, retries, user messaging, and client-side handling.

terms.name: Integration Specification
terms.definition: A detailed description of how the System interacts with external systems and services, including protocols, auth methods, data formats, and failure behavior.
terms.description: Defines integration contracts and operational expectations to reduce surprises during implementation and operation.

terms.name: Data Exchange Structures
terms.definition: Schemas and formats used for sending and receiving data between the System and external systems, including encoding and field contracts.
terms.description: Defines what data is exchanged and how it is structured to support compatibility, validation, and evolution.

terms.name: Integration Failure Behavior
terms.definition: A documented definition of system behavior when an external integration fails, including retries, fallbacks, messaging, logging, and compensation.
terms.description: Defines how failures are detected and handled to preserve user experience and system integrity under external instability.

terms.name: Resilience Patterns
terms.definition: Standardized reliability patterns such as timeouts, retries, circuit breakers, idempotency, and backoff rules applied across APIs and integrations.
terms.description: Defines common reliability rules so services behave consistently under failure and load.

terms.name: Performance Requirement
terms.definition: A quantitative expectation describing system behavior under load, such as response time, throughput, scalability, and resource usage.
terms.description: Defines measurable performance targets that drive architecture decisions, capacity planning, and test criteria.

terms.name: Scalability and Reliability Requirement
terms.definition: A technical constraint defining how infrastructure supports increased load, ensures availability, recovers from failures, and maintains predictable performance.
terms.description: Defines availability and recovery expectations that drive infrastructure topology, resilience patterns, and monitoring thresholds.

terms.name: Infrastructure Specification
terms.definition: A description of all infrastructure components and resources required to operate the Product, including compute, storage, networks, and infrastructure services.
terms.description: Defines runtime topology and resource choices needed for stable operation, scalability, and cost control.

terms.name: Environment Configuration Specification
terms.definition: A document describing all environments, their purposes, infrastructure settings, access rules, and configuration variables.
terms.description: Defines how dev/test/stage/prod differ and how configuration is managed to prevent environment drift and release surprises.

terms.name: Secrets and Configuration Management Specification
terms.definition: A structured definition of how secrets and environment variables are stored, secured, rotated, and consumed by the System.
terms.description: Defines secure handling and rotation of sensitive values to prevent leaks and support reliable deployments.

terms.name: Operational Monitoring Plan
terms.definition: A structured definition of metrics, logs, traces, and alerts required to ensure stable operation and detect incidents.
terms.description: Defines what is observed, how it is measured, and what triggers alerts to support reliability and rapid incident response.

terms.name: Operational Logging Strategy
terms.definition: A structured definition of log events, formats, correlation identifiers, storage, retention, and access rules across the System.
terms.description: Defines logging that enables debugging, auditability, and incident investigation across components and integrations.

terms.name: Deployment Pipeline Specification
terms.definition: A detailed description of steps, tools, and automation used to build, test, and deploy system artifacts, including triggers, stages, and validations.
terms.description: Defines how code becomes a running system, including quality gates and environment promotions for repeatable releases.

terms.name: Information Security Architecture
terms.definition: A structured security model describing trust boundaries, attack surfaces, and security controls mapped across system layers and components.
terms.description: Defines how protection is achieved end-to-end, including boundary assumptions, control placement, and responsibility split across services and infrastructure.

terms.name: Security Requirement
terms.definition: A technical control or rule designed to protect the System from unauthorized access, breaches, vulnerabilities, and misuse.
terms.description: Defines enforceable security expectations such as encryption, access control, auditability, and safe defaults.

terms.name: AuthN/AuthZ Architecture
terms.definition: A structured definition of authentication and authorization mechanisms across layers, including identity sources, token/session handling, and permission enforcement points.
terms.description: Defines how identity is verified and how access is enforced consistently across APIs, UI actions, and data access paths.

terms.name: Technical Risk
terms.definition: A potential issue related to feasibility, scalability, reliability, security, or integration that could impact the System, along with mitigation strategy.
terms.description: Captures risks that may block implementation or stability, including mitigations and validation actions to reduce uncertainty.

terms.name: Architecture Consistency Review
terms.definition: A structured evaluation ensuring the Technical Architecture aligns with requirements, user flows, and UI architecture without contradictions.
terms.description: Validates that architectural decisions support expected behavior and do not conflict with established product specifications.

terms.name: Architecture Completeness Review
terms.definition: A final assessment confirming all necessary architectural elements have been defined with no gaps before implementation begins.
terms.description: Checks coverage of components, data, APIs, integrations, infrastructure, security, and operational plans to avoid late discovery of missing work.

terms.name: AI System Architecture
terms.definition: A structured description of AI runtime components and interactions, including model execution, orchestration, tool calls, retrieval, and output handling.
terms.description: Defines how AI capabilities are executed end-to-end, including boundaries, dependencies, and failure handling for reliable operation.

terms.name: Model Strategy
terms.definition: A structured plan for model selection, routing, fallback behavior, cost/latency targets, and model lifecycle management.
terms.description: Defines which models are used for which tasks and how the system maintains reliability under model failures or performance constraints.

terms.name: Prompt and Output Contracts
terms.definition: A set of standardized prompt templates and strict output schemas defining required structure, validation rules, and error handling for AI outputs.
terms.description: Defines how prompts are formed and how outputs are validated to ensure determinism and safe downstream processing.

terms.name: Retrieval Architecture
terms.definition: A structured design for retrieval-augmented generation, including sources, chunking, embeddings, indexing, query strategy, and citation rules.
terms.description: Defines how the system grounds AI responses in stored knowledge and how retrieved context is selected and validated.

terms.name: Tooling Interface Specification
terms.definition: A structured definition of callable tools, permissions, input/output schemas, side effects, retries, and observability requirements for AI tool use.
terms.description: Defines how AI interacts with external capabilities deterministically, including safety constraints and failure behaviors.

terms.name: AI Quality and Evaluation Plan
terms.definition: A structured plan defining evaluation datasets, regression tests, metrics, human review gates, and monitoring for AI behavior quality.
terms.description: Defines how AI behavior is validated before release and monitored over time to prevent regressions and quality drift.

terms.name: AI Safety Controls
terms.definition: Enforceable controls for AI behavior including policy enforcement points, redaction, prompt injection defenses, rate limits, and safe tool use constraints.
terms.description: Defines how unsafe outputs and actions are prevented or mitigated, including enforcement placement and observability for violations.
